abstract.p: Letter from Stephen L Javna comments on State of the Art column on May 18 on creating backups for when hard disk crashes

block.p: Re ''To Prepare for Worst, Back Up'' (State of the Art, May 18): How do you make sure you've gotten all the bits and pieces when you back up your data? The method I now use backs up everything by using a second hard drive of the same size as the primary hard drive. The second hard drive gets operating power and data from cable connections generally provided for installation of a secondary hard drive. Then a complete mirror image of the primary drive can be created using PowerQuest's Drive Image program.

Re ''To Prepare for Worst, Back Up'' (State of the Art, May 18): How do you make sure you've gotten all the bits and pieces when you back up your data? The method I now use backs up everything by using a second hard drive of the same size as the primary hard drive. The second hard drive gets operating power and data from cable connections generally provided for installation of a secondary hard drive. Then a complete mirror image of the primary drive can be created using PowerQuest's Drive Image program.
A 6-gigabyte backup takes about eight minutes. Restoration takes about the same time. If individual backup files are required, the program provides a disk-to-disk feature.
